title: California Public Records Request: mobile device forensic tools

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: California Public Records Request: mobile device forensic tools
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records regarding the Los Angeles  county district attorney's office use of mobile device forensic tools (MDFTs). 
This includes any software, hardware, process, or service that is capable of any of the following:
• extracting any data from a mobile device,
• recovering deleted files from a mobile device, or
• bypassing mobile device passwords, locks, or other security features.
Examples of MDFTs include, but are not limited to, products or services offered by vendors such 
as Cellebrite, Grayshift, Oxygen Forensics, BlackBag Technologies, Magnet Forensics, MSAB, 
AccessData, Paraben, Katana Forensics, BK Forensics, and Guidance Software/OpenText. 
I specifically requests the following records under the California public records act 
1. Purchase Records and Agreements: Any and all records reflecting an agreement for purchase, 
acquisition, or license of MDFTs, or permission to use, test, or evaluate MDFTs since 2015. 
2. Records of Use: Any and all records describing the office use of MDFTs since 2015.
a. In particular, we seek records reflecting the office aggregate use of MDFTs. For 
example, monthly reports that reflect the total number of MDFT cases for each month, 
broken down by type of crime, and number and type of phones, and number and type of 
other devices.
i. Please specify any instances where the office used Cellebrite Advanced Services, 
or otherwise transferred possession of a device or its contents to a vendor for off-site 
processing, including Regional Computer Forensics Laboratories.
ii. Please include any instances of forensic examination of a device (e.g. using JTAG or 
chip-off processes) that may not involve a vendor’s product. 
3. Policies Governing Use: Any and all records regarding policies and guidelines governing the 
use of MDFTs, including but not limited to: training materials regarding their operation, 
restrictions on when they may be used, limitations on retention and use of collected data, 
security measures taken to protect stored and in-transit data, guidance on when a warrant or 
other legal process must be obtained, and guidance on when the existence and use of MDFTs 
may be revealed to the public, criminal defendants, or judges.
Due to the ubiquity of mobile devices, law enforcement sees the data stored on mobile devices, 
like cellphones, as key sources of evidence for investigations. However, mobile devices can 
contain large amounts of people’s sensitive and private information, much of which may be 
irrelevant to a given investigation. As the Supreme Court recognized in Riley v. 
California, “[o]ne of the most notable distinguishing features of modern cellphones is their 
immense storage capacity.” As such, forensic searches of mobile devices are often highly invasive, 
and we believe that such searches by law enforcement are increasingly common. 
Mobile device forensic tools (MDFTs) are used by law enforcement to extract data from mobile 
devices. In some cases, if the data on the mobile device is encrypted, some MDFTs can help law 
enforcement circumvent a device’s security features in order to access otherwise inaccessible 
data. These capabilities have been the subject of broad public debate, for example, in the 
aftermath of the high-profile San Bernardino shooting in 2015. Whether or not devices are 
encrypted, law enforcement’s use of MDFTs is an issue of significant public interest. 
Currently, there is a considerable lack of public information available regarding how local 
law enforcement agencies use MDFTs, and the policies and procedures that govern such 
use. The public is entitled to understand the office’s activities and capabilities with 
respect to MDFTs, and this request seeks to further the public’s understanding.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Mr. adonis gaynor

title: Obama Presidential Library: NSC Correspondence Related to Avian Flu A(H797) - 2013 to 2017

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All information, analyses, summaries, assessments, transcripts, or similar records included in National Security Correspondence related to the A(H797) strain of Avian influenza. This strain of influenza was first identified on March 31st of 2013. 

According to a Vanity Fair article that discussed the Obama administration's NSC and pandemic planning, the Obama administration was closely following the spread of A(H797) in late 2016. The article implies that the 2016 spread of A(H797) was so worrisome to Susan Rice that she decided to advocate for pandemic planning to be included in an exercise with the incoming Trump administration. 

Here's a link to the Vanity Fair article where the Obama administration's NSC response to H797 is mentioned: https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2020/05/trump-obama-coronavirus-pandemic-response?srsltid=AfmBOopglhTiQFMeUCKo_euYU2ej58tGguKPy1mDHiYXc_m_-mJ8Ln-B

The time frame for this search is from the date of A(H797)'s identification on March 31st of 2013 to the last day of the Obama administration on January 20th of 2017. The majority of documents generated by the NSC would have been in late 2016 after an outbreak among poultry in the United States and during the transition to the Trump administration. 

More on A(H797) can be found here: https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/zoonotic-influenza/facts/faq-H7N9

Thank you for the Obama Presidential Library's commitment to transparency, and I look forward to working with you until this request is granted.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robert Delaware

title: FOIA to Moore County Public Safety Office, Deputy Scot Brooks

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Deputy Brooks:

	We represent the Estate of Ramzan Daraev, who was shot and killed on May 3, 2024, at or around 1660 Dowd Road, in Carthage, North Carolina.  Under the North Carolina Public Records Law, G.S. §132-1., I am requesting an opportunity to inspect or obtain copies of public records that include:

a.	All dash-cam video footage for all police cruisers involved in this incident from 18:00 on May 3, 2024, to 23:00 on May 4, 2024 including but not limited to cruisers involved in the initial investigation, or response to the incident detailed above;

b.	All body-worn camera (BCW) video footage for all police officers involved in this incident from 18:00 on May 3, 2024, to 23:00 on May 4, 2024, including but not limited to cruisers involved in the initial investigation, or response to the incident detailed above;

c.	All public or private video footage that captures the time period of 18:00 on May 3, 2024, to 23:00 on May 4, 2024, initial investigation, or response to the incident detailed above;

d.	All radio transmissions from 18:00 on May 3, 2024, to 23:00 on May 4, 2024, to and from any police officer involved in the initial investigation, or response to the incident detailed above;

e.	All text messages, Instant Messages, or WhatsApp messages, from 18:00 on May 3, 2024, to 23:00 on May 4, 2024, to and from any police officer involved in the initial investigation, or response to the incident detailed above;

f.	All 911 Call Recordings from 18:00 on May 3, 2024, to 23:00 on May 4, 2024, regarding the incident, initial investigation, or response to the incident detailed above;

g.	All Moore County Sheriff GPS information and reports regarding any police cruiser(s) involved in the initial investigation, or response to the incident detailed above;

h.	All reports, supplemental reports, findings, notes, memorandum, emails, transcripts, communications, or any other documentation regarding the investigation of the incident detailed above; 

i.	All records from EMS Ambulance Unit M50, related to Ramzan Daraev, from the incident on May 3, 2024.

j.	All records from Fire Station 31F, related to Ramzan Daraev, from the incident on May 3, 2024. 

k.	All records from the North Carolina Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, related to the investigation of the death of Ramzan Daraev on May 3, 2024.

l.	All records indicating the chain of custody of the cell phone and vehicle, and any other personal belongings of Ramzan Daraev, as well as the current location of these items.

	If there are any fees for searching or copying these records, please inform me if the cost will exceed $500.  However, I would also like to request a waiver of all fees in that the disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest and will contribute significantly to the public’s understanding of the shooting and death of Ramzan Daraev.  This information is not being sought for commercial purposes.
The law requires that you respond to and fulfill this request "as promptly as possible."  If you expect a significant delay in responding to and fulfilling this request, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records.
If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

Thank you for considering my request.

Sincerely,


/s/Michael L. Gallagher
Michael L. Gallagher

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Michael L. Gallagher, Gallagher Law Offices, LLC

title: Jimmy Carter

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Jimmy Carter
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into former U.S. President James Earl "Jimmy" Carter Jr. (October 1, 1924 – December 29, 2024). His death is widely-known and widely reported; as such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. For example, you may find his New York Times obituary at the following link: https://www.nytimes.com/2024/12/29/us/politics/jimmy-carter-dead.html

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records of both HQ and all field offices for all relevant names, agencies, organizations, companies and events including but not limited to those cited in the previous paragraphs and/or links as well as a cross-reference with the Southern Poverty Law Center to include any information provided by the SPLC. My request includes but is not limited to 137, 157, 176, 177, 183, 184, 188, and 214 files. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

If any part of these documents are exempt from disclosure, please be sure to review and release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of responsive documents, as the FOIA requires.

I request that I be properly classified as a media requester. I am an associate editor at Reason Magazine who has written numerous articles on topics of public interest for the Daily Beast, the Asia Times, Responsible Statecraft, the National Interest, America Magazine and the Armenian Weekly, and I am requesting these documents in an editorial capacity. Please contact me if you have any questions about my media status.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Petti

title: Massachusetts clemency application processing by the Governor

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Massachusetts clemency application processing by the Governor
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

All records from the date of the Governor's revised clemency guidelines issued 10/31/23 to the date that this request is filled related to the Governor's office's processing, approval and denial of clemency applications, including:
1. Every applicant whose petition for clemency was recommended to the Governor for approval by the Advisory Board of Pardons (ABP), including date of ABP recommendation.
2. Every applicant whose petition for clemency was recommended to the Governor for denial by the Advisory Board of Pardons, including date of ABP recommendation.
3. Whether the applicant requested a pardon or a commutation.
4.  For approval recommendations that the Governor accepted, how many days between the Advisory Board of Pardons recommendation and the Governor's recommendation.
5. For approval recommendations that the Governor did not accept, what steps, if any, did the Governor take on the recommendation.
6. For approval recommendations that are still pending at this time of this inquiry, how many days have they been pending since the Advisory Board of Pardons' recommendation to the Governor (or since what date have they been pending with the Governor).

I am seeking statistical information, not personal information, so it is fine with me if applicants' names are redacted.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

David Weimer

title: Agency Roster

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Agency Roster
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;
- badge number
- employee identification number
- hire date
- rank or position
- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: WC26
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

- The full email threads involving Jeremy Racca from July/August 2024 with the subject lines "WC Host City Agreement & Potential Costs" and "City of Seattle Costs for World Cup"

- The full email thread sinvolving Tina Inay from July/August 2024 with the subject lines "FIFA WC List", "FIFA World Cup Meeting - West Coast Coordination",  "CONFIDENTIAL/TIMELY: FIFA Fan Fest 2026 / Seattle Center", "Community Partnership Meetings mentioned in the 7/15/2024 meeting re: Lumen Permitting for FIFA prep", "Community Partnerships Meeting", and "Lumen FIFA 2026 World Cup Permitting Discussion with SDCI (PA24-01503)"

- The full email threads involving Kylie Rolf from July/August 2024 with the subject lines "FIFA Community and Social Impact Subcommittee", "Strategic Partnership Opportunity for Seattle's World Cup", "Excited to join the team", "WC Budget exercise spreadsheet culling - take 1" and "FIFA / Creative Brief - strategy / city of Seattle"

- The full email thread involving Josette Wicker from July/August 2024 with the subject line "FIFA Bi-Monthly Cross Departmental Executive Planning Session"

- The full email thread involving Tim Burgess from July/August 2024 with the subject line "FIFA/DAP crosswalk"

- The full email thread involving Greg Wong from July/August 2024 with the subject line "FWC26 Permitting"

Please include attachments, linked Sharepoint documents/spreadsheets, and associated metadata.
Please do not conduct a keyword search as these are the exact subject lines for the email threads in question. If there is a way for me to make locating these email threads easier, please let me know.
Please de-duplicate emails where possible: I do not need multiple copies of the same email received by multiple people or earlier versions of an email that are reproduced in later emails. However if the earlier emails contain attachments, please include a copy of the attachment. Additionally, if there are multiple branches of a thread, please make sure each branch is reproduced.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

title: IJ Abby Meyer Remands (Department of Justice, Executive Office for Immigration Review)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. All application materials submitted by Immigration Judge Abby Meyer in connection with her appointment as a U.S. immigration judge, including cover letters, resumes, and any documents addressing quality ranking factors.

2. A redacted copy of all remands for Immigration Judge Abby Meyer ordered by the Board of Immigration Appeals

3. Copies of all judicial complaints filed with Office of IJ Conduct and Professionalism of the Executive Office for Immigration Review concerning Immigration Judge Abby Meyer.

Please search all locations and systems likely to have responsive records, regardless of format, medium, or physical characteristics.
Our request for records includes any attachments to those records or other materials enclosed with those records when they were previously transmitted. To the extent that an email is responsive to our request, our request includes all prior messages sent or received in that email chain, as well as any attachments to the email. 

Please search all relevant records or systems containing records regarding agency business. Do not exclude records regarding agency business contained in files, email accounts, or devices in the personal custody of your officials, such as personal email accounts or text messages. Records of official business conducted using unofficial systems or stored outside of official files are subject to the Federal Records Act and FOIA.

 It is not adequate to rely on policies and procedures that require officials to move such information to official systems within a certain period of time; I retain my right to records contained in those files even if the material has not yet been moved to official systems or if officials have, by intent or through negligence, failed to meet their obligations.

Please use all tools available to your agency to conduct a complete and efficient search for potentially responsive records. Agencies are subject to governmentwide requirements to manage agency information electronically,1and many agencies have adopted the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) Capstone program, or similar policies. These systems provide options for searching emails and other electronic records in a manner that is reasonably likely to be more complete than just searching individual custodian files. For example, a custodian may have deleted a responsive email from his or her email program, but your agency’s archiving tools may capture that email under Capstone. At the same time, custodian searches are still necessary; agencies may not have direct access to files stored in .PST files, outside of network drives, in paper format, or in personal email accounts.

In the event some portions of the requested records are properly exempt from disclosure, please disclose any reasonably segregable non-exempt portions of the requested records. If a request is denied in whole, please state specifically why it is not reasonable to segregate portions of the record for release.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Hassan Ahmad

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. All application materials submitted by Immigration Judge Abby Meyer in connection with her appointment as a U.S. immigration judge, including cover letters, resumes, and any documents addressing quality ranking factors.

2. A redacted copy of all remands for Immigration Judge Abby Meyer ordered by the Board of Immigration Appeals

3. Copies of all judicial complaints filed with Office of IJ Conduct and Professionalism of the Executive Office for Immigration Review concerning Immigration Judge Abby Meyer.

Please search all locations and systems likely to have responsive records, regardless of format, medium, or physical characteristics.
Our request for records includes any attachments to those records or other materials enclosed with those records when they were previously transmitted. To the extent that an email is responsive to our request, our request includes all prior messages sent or received in that email chain, as well as any attachments to the email. 

Please search all relevant records or systems containing records regarding agency business. Do not exclude records regarding agency business contained in files, email accounts, or devices in the personal custody of your officials, such as personal email accounts or text messages. Records of official business conducted using unofficial systems or stored outside of official files are subject to the Federal Records Act and FOIA.

 It is not adequate to rely on policies and procedures that require officials to move such information to official systems within a certain period of time; I retain my right to records contained in those files even if the material has not yet been moved to official systems or if officials have, by intent or through negligence, failed to meet their obligations.

Please use all tools available to your agency to conduct a complete and efficient search for potentially responsive records. Agencies are subject to governmentwide requirements to manage agency information electronically,1and many agencies have adopted the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) Capstone program, or similar policies. These systems provide options for searching emails and other electronic records in a manner that is reasonably likely to be more complete than just searching individual custodian files. For example, a custodian may have deleted a responsive email from his or her email program, but your agency’s archiving tools may capture that email under Capstone. At the same time, custodian searches are still necessary; agencies may not have direct access to files stored in .PST files, outside of network drives, in paper format, or in personal email accounts.

In the event some portions of the requested records are properly exempt from disclosure, please disclose any reasonably segregable non-exempt portions of the requested records. If a request is denied in whole, please state specifically why it is not reasonable to segregate portions of the record for release.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Hassan Ahmad
